security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill providing guidance on Hookify rule syntax. Contains no executable code, network calls, file system access, or environment variable reads. The skill only contains markdown documentation and prompt instructions.

content.value_statement: Claude Code users need guardrails to prevent dangerous operations and enforce coding standards. Hookify rules provide pattern-based warnings and reminders during development. This skill teaches the syntax and best practices for creating effective Hookify rules.
actual_capabilities: Create Hookify rules with YAML frontmatter and markdown messages
Match patterns on bash commands, file edits, prompts, or agent stops
Build simple regex patterns and advanced multi-condition rules
Use operators like regex_match, contains, equals, and starts_with
Organize rules in global (~/.claude/) or project (.claude/) locations
Test patterns with Python regex before deploying
limitations: This skill provides guidance only; it does not modify files directly
Rules require Hookify to be installed and configured
Complex patterns may need testing across different input scenarios

use_cases.title: Prevent dangerous commands
use_cases.description: Warn before rm -rf, chmod 777, or sudo operations that could harm the system.

use_cases.title: Enforce coding standards
use_cases.description: Remind developers to remove console.log, add tests, or update documentation before commits.

use_cases.title: Guard production deployments
use_cases.description: Add checklist reminders before deploying to production or modifying infrastructure.

prompt_templates.title: Basic safety rule
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating a rule to warn about rm commands
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Hookify rule that warns when the user runs rm -rf in bash. Include a clear message explaining the danger.

prompt_templates.title: File pattern rule
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Hookify rule that triggers on file events when console.log is added to .ts or .tsx files. Use conditions to match both file type and content.

prompt_templates.title: Completion checklist
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Hookify rule with event: stop that reminds the agent to run tests before finishing a task.

prompt_templates.title: Production guard
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Hookify rule for prompt events that triggers when the user mentions deploying to production. Include a checklist for deployment safety.

output_examples.input: Create a Hookify rule that warns about adding API keys to .env files
output: You are adding an API key to a .env file.
- Never commit secrets to version control
- Consider using a secrets manager for production

best_practices: Test regex patterns with Python re module before deploying rules
Use specific patterns to avoid false positives; 'console.log\(' is better than just 'log'
Place project rules in .claude/ directory and global rules in ~/.claude/
anti_patterns: Using overly broad patterns like 'rm' that match legitimate commands
Creating rules with event: all when a specific event type would be more appropriate
Forgetting to add rules to .gitignore, which could accidentally commit sensitive patterns

faq.question: What is Hookify?
faq.answer: Hookify is a system for creating pattern-based rules that trigger warnings or actions during Claude Code sessions.

faq.question: Where are Hookify rules stored?
faq.answer: Global rules go in ~/.claude/hookify.*.local.md, project rules in .claude/hookify.*.local.md.

faq.question: What events can rules trigger on?
faq.answer: Rules can trigger on bash commands, file edits, user prompts, agent stop events, or all events.

faq.question: Can Hookify block operations?
faq.answer: Yes, set action: block in the frontmatter to prevent operations. Default is warn which shows a message.

faq.question: How do I test regex patterns?
faq.answer: Use python3 -c "import re; print(re.search(r'your_pattern', 'test text'))" to test patterns.

faq.question: Should project rules be committed to git?
faq.answer: No, add .claude/*.local.md to your .gitignore to prevent accidentally committing project-specific rules.
